review.title: SLA Establishment with Guaranteed QoS in the Interdomain Network: A Stock Model
review.abstract: The new model that we present in this paper is introduced in the context of guaranteed QoS and resources management in the inter-domain routing framework. This model, called the stock model, is based on a reverse cascade approach and is applied in a distributed context. So transit providers have to learn the right capacities to buy and to stock and, therefore learning theory is applied through an iterative process. We show that transit providers manage to learn how to strategically choose their capacities on each route in order to maximize their benefits, despite the very incomplete information. Finally, we provide and analyse some simulation results given by the application of the model in a simple case where the model quickly converges to a stable state.

Finally, we provide and analyze some simulation results obtained by applying the model in a simple case where the model quickly converts to a stable state. sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION
sections.text: We have presented a new model for QoS and resource management within the cross-domain routing framework, which we have referred to as an inventory model, which is presented using a reverse cascade approach and an iterative process in which nodes could learn the right amounts of purchasing and storage capacity, and the simple simulation results we have presented confirm this model, showing that in the case of simple network topologies and / or basic strategies, the model converges towards good and satisfactory situations. Moreover, since the model converges with positive values of minimum capacity (cap _ min), it does not disadvantage vendors, but customers are not more disadvantaged as they can buy positive capacity stocks. Therefore, this model really represents an inventory model that pushes for nodes to anticipate the resource stock they can resell. However, in cases of more complex network topologies or scenarios (for example, with multiple targets), this model would need to be reinforced by more complex features and features.
